subNodes.conversationText: A young man stood on a hill above the woods. He held a book open in his left hand and with his right traced words in it as he read. It was a gray day in spring. Mist made everything wet. The young man's name, the witch knew (how?), was Malkin.

<FirstName> felt the bubblings up of unfamiliar memories and appetites. <He/She> saw a sword, a silver cup, a falling leaf fringed with orange... Two children -- was one of them Malkin, years before? -- fidgeted on the lap of an old man. The old man was speaking, but a fit of coughing cut his words short.
There were other memories: mountains in summer haze, green with mystery; the barbarities of a free and easy boyhood; a singularly beautiful face turning from him in scorn.

The memories kept Malkin from concentrating, but he knew concentration wouldn't help. The book was a disappointment. Its approaches to and retreats from revelation were both maddening and predictable, like all witchcraft. And yet he'd be scolded by the witches for taking it -- maybe worse. He rued his life with them very bitterly.
Malkin walked down the hill and into the wolf's gullet.

"And now you know his name. Tell the witch
You know it."

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY
The Three Kami: Malkin Was His Name

The young witch received a vision from a spirit about a young man named Malkin. The spirit told the young witch to mention his name to "the witch" -- presumably Eldest Lady.

subNodes.conversationText: Malkin walked down the hill into the ruined city. It crumbled as he passed. The birds went silent. Then they began to fall from the vine, head after head, and the vine went yellow and wilted.

"And now you know his name. Tell the witch
You know it."

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY
The Three Kami: Malkin Was His Name

The young witch received a vision from a spirit about a young man named Malkin. The spirit told the young witch to mention his name to "the witch" -- presumably Eldest Lady.

subNodes.conversationText: Malkin walked down the hill and through the cloudy veil. It closed behind him.

"And now you know his name. Tell the witch
You know it."
A gust of wind surprised <FirstName>. <He/She> shrieked in terror as <he/she> recalled his position and felt <his/her> support vanish.

<FirstName> plummeted from the sky above the mountain. The forest rushed to welcome <him/her>. <He/She> closed <his/her> eyes. When <he/she> opened them, <he/she> found <him/her>self suspended a few inches above the forest floor. The force that held <him/her> let <him/her> go. <He/She> heard laughter far, far away.

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY
The Three Kami: Malkin Was His Name

The young witch received a vision from a spirit about a young man named Malkin. The spirit told the young witch to mention his name to "the witch" -- presumably Eldest Lady.

subNodes.conversationText: Malkin was lying in bed at the witches' house.
"Not yet," said Middle One, though the witches' house was bright with sunlight.
"We have something to discuss with you."
Malkin was speaking, but the young witch also felt <him/her>self to be speaking. It was not very comfortable.
"You took my grimoire without asking. What did you learn?"
"I understood it, but its power was beyond mine."
"I understood it, but its power was beyond mine."
"No harm to the coven, brother. A lie is a harm."
"A lie is a harm quoth Cuckoo to Wren."
Malkin rose and looked out the window. The trees were budding. Eldest Lady was staring at him while Middle One, always skirting conflict, began cutting bacon.
"That book contains a third of my power. You've seen a little of what I can do."

"I've spent hundreds of years in idleness and contentment, rich with power I don't need to use. Can you say the same? You say you want more because you haven't enjoyed enough. What is it you want, Malkin? What are you after?"
"What is he before?" put in Middle One quietly.

"I'll tell you. You tire of the coven; you tire of us. You look at how we live and what our pleasures are and think, These two witches have nothing left to teach me. You want something you don't have words for. You dress your wants up in fine clothes and pretend they have beauties they never will. But the truth is that you want in the way other people want -- and that's fine. Everyone has things they wonder at and yearn for. Take them -- or leave them, for all I care."
"No. I want more than that," said <FirstName> in Malkin's voice.

"All desire is base. Live with it. Be human." For once, Eldest Lady sounded almost kind. "Be satisfied with the desires time gives you. They'll change, of course -- but what doesn't? Those desires are gifts, Malkin. Accept them."
"I refuse," he said. Visions flitted by: a bloody sword, a cup full of viscous white fluid, a dead leaf among other dead leaves.
He was still looking out the window. Middle One gave Eldest Lady a furtive glance.

There was a long pause, long enough for Malkin to notice. He stopped looking out the window and studied Eldest Lady. When she spoke again, her voice was different. It sounded theatrical. "You're too impatient, Malkin," said Eldest Lady. She brought out the grimoire. "Perhaps it's time. Perhaps it's time, Middle One. You should know. This book can't be read as other books are read."
Malkin's heart jumped from despondence to excitement. "Then teach me how to read it! Thats what Im here for. Im ready. I was ready before the coven. Im ready now."
"I'm a witch. You want the wisdom of spirits. Take the grimoire to them. They are the proper teachers for you now."
Yes. They are dangerous, and they could kill you... But the witch who dares steal my grimoire might demand things of them and live. Go to them without fear and they'll be less tempted."
Time passed. Malkin was gone, but <FirstName> was still there, a ghost of <him/her>self standing by the window where Malkin had stood.

Middle One was coming in from the garden, crying.

"He won't be coming back?"
"He stole from us, lied to us, betrayed us. He takes and covets, and he covets all the worse for not understanding what he covets. Hes bad, Middle One. Why should he come back?"
"He is bad. Bad and young. And we are bad and old."
"We are bad and old and a good deal more sensible."
"Beautiful but common. A daisy -- a blushing milkmaid of a witch."
"We will not see his like again."
"Oh yes we will. Besides," said Eldest Lady, "he's gone from here -- but he won't go far."

Middle One's head became the wolf's head. The tusked monster turned and looked straight at <FirstName>.

"The witches will deny their treachery.
Better now to go to him yourself.
The woodsman's child knows which path to take."
The darkness in the cave grew so deep that the witch couldn't see. Then <he/she> blinked and found <him/her>self outside.

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY
The Three Kami: The Woodcutter's Son

A second spirit showed the young witch another vision of Malkin. In it, Malkin admitted to reading Eldest Lady's grimoire and was told to seek help understanding it from the kami. After the vision faded, the spirit told the young witch that the woodcutter's son could tell them more about Malkin.

subNodes.conversationText:
A grapevine grew out of Middle One's mouth. The cluster sang:

"The witches will deny their treachery.
Better now to go to him yourself.
The woodsman's child knows which path to take."
The birds went silent. Then they began to fall from the vine, head after head, and the vine went yellow and wilted.

"The witches will deny their treachery.
Better now to go to him yourself.
The woodsman's child knows which path to take."

<FirstName> plummeted from the sky above the mountain. The forest rushed to welcome <him/her>. <He/She> closed <his/her> eyes. When <he/she> opened them, <he/she> found <him/her>self suspended a few inches above the forest floor. The force that held <him/her> let <him/her> go. <He/She> heard laughter far, far away.

The Three Kami: The Woodcutter's Son

A second spirit showed the young witch another vision of Malkin. In it, Malkin admitted to reading Eldest Lady's grimoire and was told to seek help understanding it from the kami. After the vision faded, the spirit told the young witch that the woodcutter's son could tell them more about Malkin.

subNodes.conversationText: Yes. They are dangerous, and they could kill you... But the witch who dares steal my grimoire might demand things of them and live. Go to them without fear and they'll be less tempted."
Yes. They are dangerous, and they could kill you... But the witch who dares steal my grimoire might demand things of them and live. Go to them without fear and they'll be less tempted."
Malkin's heart jumped from despondence to excitement. "Then teach me how to read it! Thats what Im here for. Im ready. I was ready before the coven. Im ready now."
"No. I want more than that," said Malkin in <FirstName>'s voice.

"All desire is base. Live with it. Be human." For once, Eldest Lady sounded almost kind. "Be satisfied with the desires time gives you. They'll change, of course -- but what doesn't? Those desires are gifts, Malkin. Accept them."

"All desire is base. Live with it. Be human." For once, Eldest Lady sounded almost kind. "Be satisfied with the desires time gives you. They'll change, of course -- but what doesn't? Those desires are gifts, Malkin. Accept them."
"It didn't interest me. I got nothing from it."

"I've spent hundreds of years in idleness and contentment, rich with power I don't need to use. Can you say the same? You say you want more because you haven't enjoyed enough. What is it you want, Malkin? What are you after?"
"We have something to discuss with you."

For the third time, the witch saw Malkin and found <him/her>self clinging to his will. <He/She> recognized the place, the hill the woodcutter's son had shown <him/her>. Around Malkin stood three huge pillars of mist that resolved themselves into the kami. Malkin had summoned them from their ancient seats, and they had come.

A bold thing, witch, to stand before us with
That book.
To call on us with restless heart.
"To bring that witch's work before us."

"WHY???" all three boomed at once.

Malkin held up the book.
"Teach me what Eldest Lady can't teach me."
"And from that book -- what do you desire?"
"To know how to read between the lines. To see what it really says."
"And what would knowing make you, witch?"
"I don't know, of course," said Malkin.

They were mocking him. He was afraid. He had invoked them, and they had indulged him by coming, but their indulgence wouldn't last. He needed to answer their question correctly, or he might not survive the interview.

"What is my hunger?" he asked himself. Society and maturity had flattened his desires and his imagination with them. Wisdom had shown him the alloy of every fantasy, the familiarity of every valley's remoteness.
He suspected that Eldest Lady was right. Now, he wanted the things other people wanted --
Love, too. But there were many things that came with love, that looked like love, that could be enjoyed.

But perhaps that resentment for what was common could bring him other blisses. Instead of accepting the world's bland gifts, he could demand more. The world had been generous with him; why shouldn't he hold it down and wring it for stronger, stranger satisfactions? To conquer, to subjugate, to glory in his own power -- these things could be tried, and with them the pursuit of beauty, of things and of people that were marvelous, lovely, and varied.

The kami shimmered, and through them he saw the forest and the horizons and the terrible pleasure at his disposal. It was as if he were looking at his childhood self from the place where the eye of childhood had seen fairlyland in some remote valley.
"TOO MUCH," the spirits said in unison.

Malkin doubled over. The young witch suddenly split off from him, all <him/her>self once again.

<He/She> watched as Malkin's skin ruptured and scabbed over. He turned toward <FirstName>, disembodied though the young witch was, and actually seemed to see <him/her>, recognize <him/her> too. Was he going to say something?

But then his limbs cleaved to his body, and his body extended and twisted itself as bones broke and muscles tore. The top of his head burst open in a fountain of blood. Its streams turned into branches, a canopy of leaves and light. What had been his mouth was now a long, thin crack in the tree that hed become.
<FirstName> heard the witches' chanting on the wind. Were they there? Or were these voices from another vision?

"Less or more, more or less,
Desires a bird without a nest.
Where it builds it cannot rest 
Less or more, more or less."

"More or less, less or more,
Times the straw its looking for
And the storm it sometimes flees,
And the branch it cannot seize,
Refugee from times great war 
More or less, less or more."
The scene melted into darkness -- all except the wolf spirit.

"Eldest Lady's trickery and his
Own folly planted him where he still stands."

"Do you not see? The Moths encircle you,
Attack the monster at your side, at every
Turn attempt your life. You are a witch --
Do you not know the Laws?"
Suddenly, <FirstName> was outside, the spirit's question ringing in <his/her> ears.

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY
Malkin's Tale

The third spirit showed the young witch what happened to Malkin when he approached the kami with Eldest Lady's grimoire: they turned him into the tree the woodcutter's son went to. The spirit blamed Eldest Lady's trickery and Malkin's hubris for this turn of events. The young witch needed to confront Eldest Lady and Middle One with this knowledge.

subNodes.conversationText: "To be fair, it seems as if you had something to do with it as well."
"Be bold but not too bold, my little witch."
"What does Malkin have to do with me?"
"What does all of this have to do with Nnenne?"
"What does Malkin have to do with me?"

"Do you not see? The Moths encircle you,
Attack the monster at your side, at every
Turn attempt your life. You are a witch --
Do you not know the Laws?"
"What does all of this have to do with Nnenne?"

"Do you not see? The Moths encircle you,
Attack the monster at your side, at every
Turn attempt your life. You are a witch --
Do you not know the Laws?"
The scene melted into the surrounding meadow -- all except the spirit's vine.

"Eldest Lady's trickery and his
Own folly planted him where he still stands."

"Do you not see? The Moths encircle you,
Attack the monster at your side, at every
Turn attempt your life. You are a witch --
Do you not know the Laws?"

The birds went silent. Then they began to fall from the vine, head after head, and the vine went yellow and wilted.
Suddenly, <FirstName> found <him/her>self on the meadow's border, the spirit's question ringing in <his/her> ears.

Love, too. But there were many things that came with love, that looked like love, that could be enjoyed.
Love, too. But there were many things that came with love, that looked like love, that could be enjoyed.

He suspected that Eldest Lady was right: he wanted the things other people wanted, maybe more intensely, maybe in different guises, but not so different. It was just that he had always been able to get more of what he wanted than other people, and satisfaction had made him resent its taste.

But perhaps that resentment for what was common could bring him other blisses. Instead of accepting the world's bland gifts, he could demand more. The world had been generous with him; why shouldn't he hold it down and wring it for stronger, stranger satisfactions? To conquer, to subjugate, to glory in his own power -- these things could be tried, and with them the pursuit of beauty, of things and of people that were marvelous, lovely, and varied.

The kami shimmered, and through them he saw the forest and the horizons and the terrible pleasure at his disposal. It was as if he were looking at his childhood self from the place where the eye of childhood had seen fairlyland in some remote valley.
"I can't answer that until you teach me how to read it."
"And what would knowing make you, witch?"
"I don't know, but I mean to find out."
"And what would knowing make you, witch?"
"I have outgrown my mentors. I seek new ones."
"And from that book -- what do you desire?"
"And from that book -- what do you desire?"
